Umai!"), another wearing a boar's head, now everyone's asleep and pretty soon the fighting begins . . .That said . . .It is a gorgeous film. The music is still top notch but I don't think it was nearly as powerful as the score in the 1st season which stuck to more traditional Japanese instruments. This is the ultimate Anime of a popular Manga/comic series, and I want to give big big big applause to Ufotable who have created this masterpiece.For those who have seen the anime series only (26 episodes), not known the full story of this film, you must go and see Rengoku-san's several "Flame-breathing" forms, which give you goose-bumps. His scenes are so super and great that make all people understand Hashira's power & strength.For those who have seen the anime and read the manga series (known full story), you also must go and see how each panel of the manga moves (it really moves!!), and enjoy comparing the scene and the panel after watching the movie (like me). You can also feel the characters' feelings more vividly than the manga series.In the end of the movie, you would be thankful and grateful for the mask, not only for anti-COVID19, but also for hiding your tears and runny noses. (this happened to me, I was so moved and emotional...) In the end, during the last song, the theater was filled with many sobbings.---- Spoilers ----
I try to minimize my spoilers here.Before the last battle, I felt that the all audience again did into "total concentration" one level deeper, and I guessed that most of them must have already read the manga series.The last battle was so so great, I have never seen such a great battle in my life that I cannot describe it with my poor English vocabulary. I can only say that it surpassed the episode 19's battle in Demon slayer anime series, and Ufotable has realized/materialized the manga 100% or more with visual, sounds, voices, backgrounds, etc.I also praise the power of Japanese professional voice actors/actress. They express the characters' feelings completely and you will be easily captured by their voice-performance. I really feel great and am proud that Japan has such great voice actors. I recommend all people in the world to see this movie with Japanese original voices with your own language subtitles, so you can listen/hear/feel their great performance.Ufotable/Aniplex did very good job to make it secret about the last battle. It was not revealed until the opening day. They also even hid the voice actor's name of the key character in the last battle. When I heard the voice in the theater, I felt like and shouted in my mind, "Wow, it's him! Yes!" Some of them in the theater must have been same like me. The voice was 100% fit and so convincing that I was like persuaded to become a de....Anyway, please enjoy (with tears)! Months before the Demon Slayer TV series hit Netflix UK,I became aware of the film version,after seeing on Charting with Dan Murrell reports of it breaking box office records in Japan,at a time when think pieces were claiming that the death of cinema was about to take place. Finding just one showing taking place at my local cinema,I got set to at last board the train.View on the film:Revealing that season 2 of the show will follow the aftermath of the movie, the screenplay by the "Ufotable" team adapts Koyoharu Gotouge's Manga with a gripping continuation of the hero's journey which Tanjiro Kamado is on, which is tied into nightmare lucid dreams that blur the lines between the demon slaying Horror fighting with Enmu,and the personal demons which haunt Tanjiro's memories.Not limited in this case to the runtime of under 30 minutes that each episode has, series director Haruo Sotozaki makes a dazzling feature film debut,with spectacular,ultra-stylised hand-drawn animation drawing the Gothic Horror demon slaying across the screen,as slick panning shots run across the colourful, detailed battle sequences.Cleverly,using CGI in a limited manner, Sotozaki blends the contrasting formats to paint a depth of field in the spectacular Akaza becoming one with the train,which goes off the rails towards an explosive, emotionally charged final confrontation between Akaza and Rengoku, as Tanjiro wakes from his nightmare to slay a demon.

None of them knowing that this is all part of a plan orchestrated by one of lower rank Kizuki Enmu. *Disclaimer* it is worth noting that unlike most films that are non-canon to the main story. This film is Canon to the manga and if you haven't watched the first season or read to the rehabilitation arc then this movie is a huge spoiler. The first half of the story is more character driven as we delve into the dreams, the minds of the characters. The most part inosuke and Zenitsu don't really have much to offer until later on. The main focus of the story in kept on Rengoku and Tanjiro. The two of quickly develop a bond between them and Kyojuro offers him wisdom that Tanjiro takes to heart as he still blames himself for his family death. Second-half comes around this is where things start to really get intense. The fighting is so crisp and clean this a feature length that's to be expected. However when you actually look at it you can see just how close the show is to this quality. They're are just so over the top and intense especially near the finale you can get lost in it. The setting is of course on a train which offers a compact secluded environment, but if you're expected to see multiple locations you'll be just a little disappoint the entire film takes place on the train. Overall the movie the first looks like it's gonna be more slow burn her things do escalated rather quickly start it and it offers an interesting story intense action and stunning Visuals. The music is beautiful and the visuals and animation is beautiful, once again offering a perfect mixture between CG and Hand drawn.

reviews.review_title: What you think about this movie depends on what you think about the series
reviews.content: Demon Slayer: Mugen Train is a movie that was looked forward to universally with as much hype as possible. And when it eventually did come out, the reviews were great and so was its box office performance. And ever since, this movie has been a pretty big deal amongst the anime community.I finally was able to watch it, and I guess I'm a little underwhelmed by the whole thing. My reaction to this movie was very similar to how I felt about the series, and I think the same can be said of everyone. The series, in my opinion, is a decently enjoyable B-Tier anime with 1 exceptionally phenomenal episode. But that's just my take on it and I'm aware I'm in the minority here, because the amount of love this series has garnered is almost unbelievably massive and universal. So what Mugen Train caters to is exactly that demographic of fans (as so it should), meaning that for someone like me who found very little to go crazy about in the series, would find very little to go crazy about in this movie. But if you're one of those who loved the series for its goofiness and style, then this movie is in every way a treat.I don't think Mugen Train was a bad movie in any way. It was decently enjoyable and had its little moments. The plot is pretty straight forward but makes very little sense if you even stop to think about it. The progress was lazily convenient and the stakes never felt real until at the very end of the movie. The humor was pretty goofy and the characters were as over-the-top as they were in the series... Enjoyable, still The animation was pretty good and consistent throughout; especially the action scenes that were choreographed as well as they were in the series. The colors, the visuals, the music... they're all pretty great and add to the visually pleasing appeal of the movie.In conclusion, this movie doesn't add anything to the medium in any meaningful way, but it stays true to its style and convention as that is what people love most about the Demon Slayer universe. If you loved the series, you'll love this movie... Go for it!

reviews.review_title: Potent visual and auditory highs met by a story that leaves too much in the tank
reviews.content: I so desperately wanted this film to blow my mind and become my new favorite of all time. It has been a long time coming for shonen anime to capitalize on American markets in a big way. I have no doubts that Demon Slayer will find great financial success here, given that it is the top box office of all time in Japan and the market for season 1 of the show was huge here. I just wish it blew the doors open in an even bigger way.Mugen train is a direct continuation of season 1 of the wildly popular anime Demon Slayer. The animation in the show was already impressive, but it was promised that the studio behind the movie is in an entirely different league. This turned out to be true and then some, with some of the most pulse-pounding, breath-taking action animation I have ever seen. What can't be understated is the brilliant score that pushed these animations to new heights.The story is gripping, with few dull moments and no plot holes. It even had some big surprises that turn the story on a dime. The problem I had with it is that I expect more from shonen anime. I expect some sense of doom and gloom when the protagonist realizes that the antagonist is far beyond his/her power, or vice versa. I expect an even greater threat to be introduced upon the conclusion of any victory. Demon Slayer does both of these things, but meekly.Ultimately, this is a great movie to watch in theatres for the spectacle, even if you haven't seen the show. Seeing the show may add some more depth to the jokes or empathy for the characters, but it certainly isn't necessary. I recommend this film to anyone who has the maturity to brush off the stereotypes of who should or shouldn't go to a shonen anime in theatres.

Its tricky to write a review for this one because it is not really an usual movie but it's an anime arc and a very serious and the detailed one indeed. As a movie, it was beautiful I would say. Throughout the movie, you would feel various emotions. Some scenes are cute and wholesome, some are sad, filled with regrets, there is a bit of comic relief as well. You may find yourself having a good laugh initially but the ending is sad and emotional.Now, coming back to reviewing it as an arc, this is how it overall went :Story : Beautifully executed. Even though, Enmu was dealt sooner than we expected, the writing is totally justified. We didn't really get to see how Inosuke managed to wake up and break free of that dream but apart from that it was all no-nonsense stuff. There was a thrill but no unnecessary stretching or no unnecessary badasseries. There are few comic relief and cute moments as well. Also, there are quite few classy quotes and I can't get enough of them.Characters : We cannot say that both the villains were purposeless. They are demons and are brilliantly written. By the end of the movie, their respective mindsets were described pretty well. Rengoku too is brilliantly written but I felt we deserved to know more about his father or Rengoku's viewpoint about his father. I am not really sure if we get to know more about him in the upcoming arc. Regardless, Rengoku seemed closer to his mother. Tanjirou as usual a very wholesome character and keeps giving you various feels. But overall, the show belonged to Inosuke. If you guys were waiting for his character development, this is that moment. The movie doesn't offer much to Zenitsu and Nezuko fans but despite that, they do have their respective moments. And rest assured, you will definitely get to hear "Kaminari no kokyu, ichi no kata. Hekireki Issen!!!"Art : Outstanding animation. Combined with sound effects, it almost feels like a never-seen-before stuff.Sound : I am yet to browse the titles but one thing is for sure, each of those OSTs are absolute fire. We could not have asked for better. Rengoku fans should not miss the end credits.Overall, I enjoyed every bit of this movie.

These days it's not easy for us to go out to leisure facilities, needless to say, due to covid-19. Movie theaters are a few exceptions even in Japan where the infection hasn't been relatively severe. That most foreign films don't play this year helps only domestic films such as "Demon Slayer" play unusually many times a day.Covid also brought a serious blow to Japanese businesses which had already been in an economic slump for many years. Particularly in the pandemic era, people are likely to lose their ways and not have an idea of what they should do.Demons originally symbolize unknown terrors to humans like earthquakes, eruptions, floods, or plague. The very classic storyline, "a brave boy who has a sense of justice beats demons", gives people hope for salvation and brings about catharsis. The old-fashioned and creepy ambiance depicted by a lavish, high-quality animation exactly fits with the current time.

... as this is now the highest-grossing film in Japan by a very long shot. It made 40 billion Yen followed by "Spirited Away" with almost 32 billion (and "Titanic" with a measly 26 billion). Impeccable. The characters? Immaculate. My main issue with the first season of the show was that Inosuke and Zenitsu were beyond infuriating and were on 100% with their personalities 100% of the time. It was still like this in the first third of the movie, but the characters show some other aspects of their personalities as well, and are slightly more tame during the latter half, which I think the majority of the American audience will greatly appreciate. Another issue I had with the first season was that the audience was never able to properly grieve with Tanjiro over his family's death, as they were given less than five minutes of screen time during the original. I'm not going to spoil anything but that has been addressed now, and I've shed tears for them now, or at least for how much their loss impacted Tanjiro. Oh and back to the art direction. You can tell that every single person on akira matsusima's team gave it their all, and loved every minute of it. Every frame bleeds passion, and some left my jaw hanging. The dedication and attention to detail is evident and I cannot give it high enough praise. I am left very curious as to how the show will go on with Tanjiro as the main character without it feeling underwhelming though, now that we see how much his powers pale in comparison to the high ranking slayers and demons. I'm worried it may have went too crazy too soon but we'll have to find out when season two releases. The sound design was astounding as well. I'm obviously no professional movie reviewer, and I may be a little biased because I love Shonen and am a sucker for art, but I honestly found nothing wrong with this movie and really hope I'm not overhyping it when I say- even if you're not a fan of anime as a genre you're doing yourself a great disservice by not seeing this film. What's more, all of the action in the movie was the equivalent of slamming action figures into one another and declaring one of them the victor by screaming exposition at you as to how you should feel about what just happened.Example: Person A slams into Demon-thing B. Flash! Bang! Excitement! A and B separate, breathing heavily. Character C, not involved, says something to the effect of, "Wow, A really took a beating there, he can't take much more of that." Then they go back at it and it repeats.When there are no rules and normal physics don't apply, it's impossible to care about the outcome of any given conflict. It's just at the mercy of the writers deciding which action figure gets to win this conflict.To further emphasize this, during one scene, a character is hit by a giant Demon-Tentacle, and wham, he's slammed into the wall, you'd be done for if it were you. He's fine though. Okay, so this character is strong.Then, literally 1 scene later, this same character is stabbed by something the size of a pencil, and it's practically a death-sentence. He's out of the fight for the rest of the movie.Another character is literally impaled on something's arm, and manages to almost cut its head off anyway, but then the character dies.Why? Give me rules!!!! If character's can be literally impaled and bleeding but summon the strength to scream some nonsense and then burst into flames, what are the limits?!? What am I meant to be impressed by? Has he done something amazing or is he a terrible swordsman? It's impossible for me to tell because there aren't any rules. Soon enough though, character C comes on screen to scream how I should feel, so that I can continue.All-in-all, if you've seen the anime, and you enjoyed that, give it a watch. We're at the cinema though, this is the first film I've seen on a big screen in nearly two years. It needs to be seen on a big screen really, it's all about the spectacle. This is a shame seeing as it's only screening for one day in the UK. The plot. It's pretty straightforward. There are demons, that are bad and demon slayers, that are good. Some young slayers including Tanjiro, his sister who's in a box with a muzzle because she's a demon (but a good one) and a dude wearing a boar mask (I thought he was a boar for a large part of the film) are boarding a train to meet and learn from a Hashira who's some kind of demon slayer master who doesn't blink. He's there though to protect the passengers from a demon on board, who seems styled on one of Tim Burton's fantasies, with a detachable hand with its own mouth that's reminiscent of Thing from the Addams Family. It's very trippy, our heroes attacked in their dreams as they're put to sleep, the demon taking over the train in a weird flubber meets The Abyss tendrils, with millions of eyes that pop out of nowhere. It looks very cool. There is an odd mix of animation styles though, from quite simple flat comic book stuff to scenes with beautiful depth. The fight scenes though of which there are many are where it excels. The pace is blistering, the screen awash with colour as as techno rock score blasts away. It's pretty frenetic and to be honest the story is very simple at its core. It's fun though, but I'm not sure I'll be getting into the TV show. I've already missed three seasons. The story is about 4 member of the kisatsutai (demon slayer corps), tanjiro, nezuko, zenitsu, and inosuke, (yes, nezuko is considered as a member of demon slayer corps even though she's a demon), boarding a train to meet the Flame Hashira, Kyojuro Rengoku, to help him on a mission to hunt an upper moon demon. reviews.content: This movie was amazing. I must admit that I had just watched Demon Slayer Season 1 before seeing this with my friend. I really enjoyed demon slayer season 1 but this movie does everything the show set out to de even better. Let's start out with the intro. Immediately after the movie is introduced with the master getting old you knew this had to be a movie as they set this movie up in a way where you know it had to be a movie which was a concern if mine. I was concerned that the movie would feel like 6 episodes smashed together but that's not what it felt like at all. It truely did feel like one story being told in an hour and fifty seven minutes. Anyways, the movie gets straight into the action without spending any time on a recap and we are immediately introduced to Rengoku. I say introduced because although we have seen him in the first season we didn't truely get a feel for his entire personality but this scene perfectly establishes how over the top Rengoku really is. Then, we get right into the action with Rengoku having to fight a demon. Immediately something that you'll notice if you do see this in a theater or if you have surround sound or a sound bar is that the sound design of this movie is amazing. I don't know if it's just because it was my first time going back to a theater but I definitely think that the sound design on this movie is far above average. Anyways, the demon ends up putting all of the main characters to sleep and we get to see their dream sequences. I like Zenitsu's dream sequences a lot and Rengoku'd gives a lot of insight into his childhood. Tanjiro's dream was great as well and definitely focused on just the lengths he would go to to get back with his family. Eventually though he realizes he has to kill himself to get out of the dream so two he does and he wakes up then he gets the others to wake up and he goes in top of the train to fight the demon. I absolutely loved the sequence where the screen was covered in blood and the demon was putting words into the mouths of Tanjiro's family. It was truely a very powerful scene. The train turning into a demon was probably the worst part of the movie but great nonetheless. The CG on the demon is a little jarring though I must admit. But the best part of this sequence is the fact that the train really was a demon as I Inosuke had presumed in the beginning. Let's move on to the section off of the train which is far and away the best part of the movie. At first, when they got off the train I thought it was the end of the movie and I was kind of underwhelmed but boy was I wrong. Upper Moon 3 shows up and Rebgoku has to fight him. This makes for what is, in my opinion, better than the fight in episode 19. In fact I would call this the series' new best fight. The music they used for Upper Moon 3 was just great It was heartwrenching to see Rengoku die as by the end of the movie they really do make you care about Rengokuat and the action was great too. Every shot was animated absolutely beytaigully and I loved what Rengoku'd final blow looked like and when Rengoku asks his mother right before dying if he did a goodjob it's heart-breaking. We end the movie off how it started with the master and I forgot to mention that all of the Hashira finding out is sad as well and done perfectly. So, overall, I have no complaints with this movie. This is the first movie I've ever seen where I wanted to see it again immediately after I saw it the first time. I would definitely reccomended this if you watched the series to anyone and if you haven't watched the series watch it and then watch this movie.

(Reviewing subbed version) As a fan of the manga and anime, I had high expectations. They were met. Then they were blown away.Visually, Mugen Train is a unique work of art. Then a chibi pops up to mix things up some more.The fight scenes are beautiful splashes and slashes of fire, water, and lightning. There's not as much blood as I thought there'd be, but that just made it so when it DID flow, the sympathetic pain was greater.Like the series, though, Mugen Train has a trainload of humor, and the writers, seiyuus, and animators deftly incorporate it into the narrative. Inosuke flying off the handle, Zenitsu drooling over Nezuko, Rengoku's eating habits, smol Nezuko... is funny.The Seiyuus did an excellent job, taking their performances over the top, perfectly matching the visuals.There are a few spots here and there where inconsistent animation messes with the pacing, and only true fans of anime-those who are not only forgiving of extreme melodrama-won't think the ending dragged a bit. But little things can't take away from the awesomeness of Mugen Train.

reviews.review_title: A simple but great movie with godly animation and music
reviews.content: I've always found the animated version of Demon Slayer to be a great experience. There is great music, godly animation. This movie of course is no exception and goes beyond even what season one of the anime did (which was already amazing in those two departments). If you're a fan of simple stories with endearing characters this will be highly entertaining to watch. Tanjiro and Rengoku especially stand out in the series and in this film. They are characters that most people would find difficult to not like.The story is simple and isn't anything any mindblowing so it does puzzle me a tiny bit that it broke the records it did. Most Shonen Jump (Battle Manga) movies would have a similar story in them such as DBS: Broly or One Piece: Stampede but Demon Slayer has exploded in Japan for various reasons.While the story is simple and errs on the generic side for the most part it isn't bad. Most people would sympathize with Rengoku's story and many would probably tear up during Tanjiro's dream. One other thing that I will commend the story on is that a major supporting character died. Of course it wasn't Tanjiro but a major supporting character in the series. In the scope of this movie, Rengoku was the main character so really the main character of this film died by the end which is something that doesn't happen very often in similar films (like in One Piece or Dragon Ball). If you were to ask someone watching this for the first time if they thought Rengoku would be dead by the end of this film and not have killed Akaza, it would be a unanimous no. It's almost certain that most would not have seen this coming. For the hero to only be unable to defeat the main villain but also perish. Of course, this is also in a literal sense. We, the audience know that Rengoku won in a spiritual sense. Even though he perished he was able to force an Upper Rank Demon to flee and protected everyone else.It's still an enjoyable watch and this adaptation is in my opinion a massive upgrade from the manga version. The manga is ok at best. The art, especially at the beginning wasn't great to put it lightly and the Mugen Train Arc was drawn in those early chapters so it did suffer from this problem.However, in this movie the art, animation and music massively boost the quality of this arc up thanks to Ufotable having a team of amazing animators. In a way you could say that the animators hired to work on this movie are the Hashira of the anime industry. Everything looked beautiful in this movie. The best animated scene had to be when Rengoku slashed Akaza (with his 9th Form: Rengoku) and had to move his sword in a different direction. That looked stunning.The special effects looked amazing (such as Rengoku's fire tiger) and the CGI fit seamlessly. The demon who fused with the train had his new reddish, grotesque body shown through CGI and it looked great.When CGI is shown in anime there is an astoundingly high chance that it will be terrible. The characters and models will look stiff and feel like they came from a video game, especially when they're next to a 2D-drawn character. This can ruin a lot of scenes because it looks out of place when next to hand-drawn characters.In conclusion, if you're a fan of Demon Slayer then you've already seen this epic movie. If you're not a fan and haven't watched the preceding arcs then I would say this is ok to watch as well. This movie won't blow your mind away in terms of story so if you're looking for some complex film you won't find it here. The plot and characters are simple enough that anyone will be to decipher who these characters are and their motivations through this movie without too much backstory. The dreams everyone had on the train especially helps fill in the clues on their motivations and pasts. If you're at all a fan of godly animation and music then is also a must-watch.

reviews.review_title: If you have watched the first season of demon slayer, it is a must watch movie!!
reviews.content:
I watched this movie with my friend after the final examination. This movie shines in my life after the nightmare final examination week.
Story:
The movie is the sequel of the anime series. The movie starts with the scene on the train where the main characters show up. In the entire film we will stick around with this train as a background which is pretty interesting to me. Using the train as background gives me the feeling about the long journey. The film-makers put the conversation that allows us to learn more about the detail and background story of the character from the series season one. This makes us more connected to the character. Moreover, there are some scenes that have meaningful speech which the audience can understand easily. However, there are some scenes that went too far from my expectations.
Character:
There are improvements in the characters that appear in this movie. Characteristics and identities are more visible than the previous series installment.Animation + Sound effects:
I could say this is one of the best animated films in terms of animation that I've ever watched. Sound effect, scores, voice acting, everything fits in this movie at the top..Verdict: Overall, it is a movie that is worth watching as a Friday night's movie. The storyline is decent, the graphics are well-animated and other things that I haven't mentioned can make you enjoy this movie. If you are free from anything else, I highly recommend this movie for you. :D
